sourceMeaningMnemonic:
A <radical>gambler</radical> sets <radical>fire</radical> to his home in order to <kanji>bake</kanji> some goods and <kanji>cook</kanji> a turkey. Setting his house on fire isn’t exactly the brightest idea, but the gambler is taking a gamble that the things he baked and cooked in the fire will offset the cost of a new home. 

This kanji also means <kanji>burn</kanji>, because when you cook or bake something for too long, that's exactly what it does.
meaningInfo: Feel the fiery flames around you as you smell the smell of baked goods and cooked meat in your nostrils.
readingMnemonic: This gambler used to play for the New York <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (<ja>や</ja>). He had a pitching injury, developed a gambling problem, and also took up some hobbies to <kanji>bake</kanji> and <kanji>cook</kanji>. Certainly a departure from his time with the Yankees.
readingInfo: Imagine this guy running around cooking in the fire of his home, only this time with a Yankees hat and jersey on. He doesn’t play for them anymore, but he still loves the team.
